>> 4) How will you deal with the stochastic evaluation situation created by
>> module-module co-evolution. Consider this case: two modules (A and B)
>> compose network X. Under your algorithm (if I understand correctly) A gets
>> an evolution phase, B gets an evolution phase, and then X evolves one
>> generation. So now when we come back to A's evolution phase, the
>> population fitness rankings may have completely changed, because fitness
>> is dependent on B's evolution is well. In modular NEAT this proved to be
>> the biggest weak point in the algorithm, since it yielded no real module
>> evolution (if you read the paper: modules evolved to be /highly/
>> generalist, and then it turned out that only bindings really mattered for
>> fitness).
>
> This depends a great-deal on what type of modules you are attempting to
> implement.  Remember the discussion of "modularity and interfaces" from
> earlier in the year (http://groups.yahoo.com/group/neat/message/1871).  If
> the modules were just encoded by parts of the genome, then no fitness
> separate from the fitness of the whole would be required (just as, even
> though the same gene might be present in multiple genomes, there's no need
> to try to calculate a cross-population fitness for it).

Sure -- thats a more natural way to do it, but in this case I think Ashot 
is (or was, at least) proposing evolving the modules in a separate 
population. So dependent credit assignment is going to be a problem, as 
you point out. (It can be lessened in NNs somewhat by making modules 
encode complete input->output pathways, though).

Actually nature has a very clever way to measure how "good" a certain 
modularization is (without resorting to assigning a fitness to each 
module). Basically you can imagine two genotypes that map to the exact 
same phenotype, but say genotype A encodes the phenotype in a very modular 
way, whereas genotype B uses no modules. Both genotypes would have equal 
fitness, but if the fitness regime was dynamic (i.e. the fitness-function 
changes over time), then it turns out that genotype A is more "evolvable." 
In other words, its modular organization makes it better at adapting when 
the selection pressure changes. This will make it more successful over the 
long-run, even though its instantaneous fitness is the same. Thus the 
"goodness" of a certain modularization can actually be measured to some 
extent as evolvability (of course evolvability depends on other things, 
like neutral traits for example, but I don't see these as being really 
separate from modularity in biology).
